DataElement.preferredName: Biospecimen Prevalent or Associated Histologic Subtype Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The response indicating the predominant histologic subtypes of lung adenocarcinoma or squamous cell carcinoma detected in the lung tissue sample.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Biospecimen Prevalent or Associated Histologic Subtype
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products.:Widespread, especially in a particular area or at a particular time._An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise._Joined in some kind of relationship._The classification of tumors based on their histology.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products.

Concepts.definition: Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products.

Concepts.definition: Widespread, especially in a particular area or at a particular time.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma originating in the lung. Lung carcinomas usually arise from the epithelium that lines the bronchial tree (bronchogenic carcinomas), and are classified as small cell or non-small cell carcinomas. Non-small cell lung carcinomas are usually adenocarcinomas, squamous cell carcinomas, or large cell carcinomas. Metastatic carcinomas to the lung are also common, and can be difficult to distinguish from primary tumors._The classification of tumors based on their histology.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant tumor arising from secreting cells of a racemose gland, particularly the salivary glands. Racemose (Latin racemosus, full of clusters) refers, as does acinar (Latin acinus, grape), to small saclike dilatations in various glands. Acinar cell carcinomas are usually well differentiated and account for about 13% of the cancers arising in the parotid gland. Lymph node metastasis occurs in about 16% of cases. Local recurrences and distant metastases many years after treatment are common. This tumor appears in all age groups and is most common in women. (Stedman, 25th ed; Holland et al., Cancer Medicine, 3d ed, p1240; from DeVita Jr et al., Cancer: Principles & Practice of Oncology, 3d ed, p575)

Concepts.definition: A malignant glandular epithelial neoplasm consisting of secretory cells forming acinar patterns. Representative examples include the acinar cell carcinoma of the pancreas and the acinar adenocarcinoma of the prostate gland.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Thirty Percent Unit Lung Acinar Adenocarcinoma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A natural number greater than twenty-nine and less than thirty-one and the quantity that it denotes._A unit for expressing a number as a fraction of hundred (on the basis of a rate or proportion per hundred)._A morphologic variant of lung adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of acinar structures composed of columnar or cuboidal cells. (NCI05)

Concepts.definition: A natural number greater than twenty-nine and less than thirty-one and the quantity that it denotes.
A unit for expressing a number as a fraction of hundred (on the basis of a rate or proportion per hundred).
A morphologic variant of lung adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of acinar structures composed of columnar or cuboidal cells. (NCI05)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A carcinoid tumor of the lung showing focal necrotic changes or a number of mitotic figures between 2 and 10/10 high power fields.

Concepts.definition: A neuroendocrine tumor of the lung showing focal necrotic changes or a number of mitotic figures between 2 and 10/10 high power fields.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Squamous Cell Lung Carcinoma, Basaloid Variant
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic variant of squamous cell lung carcinoma characterized by nuclear palisading. (NCI05)

Concepts.definition: A morphologic variant of squamous cell lung carcinoma characterized by nuclear palisading.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A well-differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the lung periphery. It resembles colorectal adenocarcinoma with acinar and/or cribriform architecture and papillotubular structures.

Concepts.definition: A well-differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the lung periphery. It resembles colorectal adenocarcinoma with acinar and/or cribriform architecture and papillotubular structures.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An aggressive variant of lung adenocarcinoma that exhibits a micropapillary architectural pattern. The prognosis is usually poor.

Concepts.definition: An aggressive variant of lung adenocarcinoma that exhibits a micropapillary architectural pattern. The prognosis is usually poor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A very rare lung adenocarcinoma in situ variant characterized by the presence of tall columnar cells with basal nuclei and abundant cytoplasmic mucin.

Concepts.definition: A very rare lung adenocarcinoma in situ variant characterized by the presence of tall columnar cells with basal nuclei and abundant cytoplasmic mucin.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic variant of lung adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of papillary structures.  (NCI05)

Concepts.definition: A morphologic variant of lung adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of papillary structures.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Prostate Carcinoma Metastatic in the Lung
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma that arises from the prostate gland and has spread to the lungs.

Concepts.longName: Prostate Carcinoma Metastatic in the Lung
Concepts.definition: A carcinoma that arises from the prostate gland and has spread to the lungs.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from squamous epithelial cells.  Morphologically, it is characterized by the proliferation of atypical, often pleomorphic squamous cells.  Squamous cell carcinomas are graded by the degree of cellular differentiation as well, moderately, or poorly differentiated.  Well differentiated carcinomas are usually associated with keratin production and the presence of intercellular bridges between adjacent cells.  Representative examples are lung squamous cell carcinoma, skin squamous cell carcinoma, and cervical squamous cell carcinoma.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from squamous epithelial cells.  Morphologically, it is characterized by the proliferation of atypical, often pleomorphic squamous cells.  Squamous cell carcinomas are graded by the degree of cellular differentiation as well, moderately, or poorly differentiated.  Well differentiated carcinomas are usually associated with keratin production and the presence of intercellular bridges between adjacent cells.  Representative examples are lung squamous cell carcinoma, skin squamous cell carcinoma, and cervical squamous cell carcinoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Solid Lung Adenocarcinoma with Mucin Production
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic variant of lung adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of polygonal malignant cells forming sheets. Acinar, papillary, micropapillary, or lepidic growth patterns are absent.  If the tumor is 100 percent solid, intracellular mucin should be present in at least five tumor cells in each of two high-power fields and confirmed with mucin immunohistochemical stains. Tumors formerly classified as large cell carcinomas expressing pneumocyte immunohistochemical markers, even if intracellular mucin is absent, are now included in this category.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic variant of lung adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of polygonal malignant cells forming sheets. Acinar, papillary, micropapillary, or lepidic growth patterns are absent.  If the tumor is 100 percent solid, intracellular mucin should be present in at least five tumor cells in each of two high-power fields and confirmed with mucin immunohistochemical stains. Tumors formerly classified as large cell carcinomas expressing pneumocyte immunohistochemical markers, even if intracellular mucin is absent, are now included in this category.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: 4/22/19 jk Updated definition to match current NCIt.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A carcinoid tumor of the lung characterized by the absence of necrosis and the presence of less than 2 mitoses per 10 high power fields.

Concepts.definition: A neuroendocrine tumor of the lung characterized by the absence of necrosis and the presence of less than 2 mitoses per 10 high power fields.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma originating in the lung. Lung carcinomas usually arise from the epithelium that lines the bronchial tree (bronchogenic carcinomas), and are classified as small cell or non-small cell carcinomas. Non-small cell lung carcinomas are usually adenocarcinomas, squamous cell carcinomas, or large cell carcinomas. Metastatic carcinomas to the lung are also common, and can be difficult to distinguish from primary tumors._The classification of tumors based on their histology._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma originating in the lung. Lung carcinomas usually arise from the epithelium that lines the bronchial tree (bronchogenic carcinomas), and are classified as small cell or non-small cell carcinomas. Non-small cell lung carcinomas are usually adenocarcinomas, squamous cell carcinomas, or large cell carcinomas. Metastatic carcinomas to the lung are also common, and can be difficult to distinguish from primary tumors.

Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ClassificationSchemes.longName: CCG PTCL (Center for Cancer Genomics - Peripheral T Cell Lymphoma)

ReferenceDocuments.name: PQT
ReferenceDocuments.description: Prevalent subtype of ADC or associated type for SCC
